instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP5V_S4_RS3: What is PP5V_S4_RS3? This is a typo of PP5V_S4RSE When you see PP5V_S4_RS3, assume they meant to type PP5V_S4RSE.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello,
i am working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not turning on. Some S3 Rails are missing. I followed this path and the enables and <SIGNAL>PM_LSP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are missing. On two sections of the board (<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R5151</RESISTOR>) i could find some minor sights of corrosion but no damaged Parts/traces there. I attached a picture of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. Bios resistors and traces look fine too. Now i am stuck. 
Thank you for any help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 5V coming on at L7520? If that does not come on it will be power cycling and nothing else will work. Seems like <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> could be dead or corroded trace/resistor there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: L7520 has 0.0V on it but no short there. Can there be 5V if <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are not there?. I exchanged <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> to be sure it is fine and there are no corroded traces. But still no change. On the other side of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is created (3.3V on L7560) so i assume that <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is working fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: PPVRTC is there. <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and the surrounding areas look fine. i took a close look of the complete board but nothing else is looking bad except for one Ground probe point that was a little corroded... Should i put it in the ultrasonic if i can´t find any visual damage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Sure why not. You did check for power cycling, hard to catch on a multimeter, impossible on an autorange one. Best to use a scope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: the cleaning also did not help. Any other Ideas what can cause this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Make a picture of what <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> looks like now. Did you check for pulsing on all rails, preferably with a scope. Checked all rails for short to GND?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No Title

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, are all there and stable. Other rails are missing because <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If anything is wrong it will be power cycling. You cannot just say <SIGNAL>SLP_S4</SIGNAL> is missing without checking for power cycling. Hard to catch on many multimeters, impossible on auto ranging ones.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I´ll see if i can get a scope soon. Anything special to look for when buying one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Nah, you can do this with an old free bee CRT thing...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I got a scope now and checked all present rails for pulsing but i couldn´t find any unsteady rails. So can i say that it is not power cycling or did i do it wrong? But still no 5V on L7520...  I´m really confused when <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The rail to check for power cycling would be the 5V rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_RS3</SIGNAL> is straight 0V. No pulsing or anything noticeable on the scope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> all 4 resistors should have about 3V on both pins, also check voltage on <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> both pins...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: all resistors measure fine and there are 3-3.3V on all pins (<RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> = 8.58V) so i assume everything is fine there

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It could be that the 3V or 5V spiked when water hit <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. Measure resistance to GND on both rails and compare to a good board. Otherwise I am out of ideas besides crap under the SMC.
